docs.lead_paragraph: Jean-Claude Mas, the founder of a French company that made hundreds of thousands of breast implants from industrial-grade silicon, was detained early on Thursday.

headline.seo: Jean-Claude Mas, Founder of Breast Implant Company, Is Detained
headline.main: French Police Detain Founder of Breast Implant Maker
headline.print_headline: French Police Detain Man Who Founded Implant Maker

docs.abstract: Jean-Claude Mas, founder of now-defunct French company Poly Implants Protheses that made hundreds of thousands of breast implants from cheap and unapproved industrial-grade silicone, is detained in his home in southern France; has not been charged with any crime but could be held for questioning in a manslaughter investigation that began after a woman whose implants ruptured died from a rare form of cancer.
docs.snippet: Jean-Claude Mas, the founder of a French company that made hundreds of thousands of breast implants from industrial-grade silicon, was detained early on Thursday.

byline.original: By MAÏA DE LA BAUME and DAVID JOLLY

docs.abstract: President Obama should keep the focus on unfairness, not inequality.
docs.snippet: President Obama should keep the focus on unfairness, not inequality.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's choice to emphasize fairness rather than equality in the State of the Union address makes good political sense. Although equality is the central concern of the Occupy Wall Street movement, focused as it is on income disparities, Americans are at least ambivalent toward equality as a primary value. They think emphasizing equality was O.K. in the context of the Civil War and segregation because inequality was institutionalized in those days and it is a good thing those days are over.
docs.abstract: President Obama should keep the focus on unfairness, not inequality.
docs.snippet: President Obama should keep the focus on unfairness, not inequality.

headline.main: A Quick Roundup of the Pentagon's Proposed Budget Cuts

docs.abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta outlined on Thursday the first major step - he called it a "down payment" - of shrinking the Pentagon after a decade of war.
docs.snippet: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta outlined on Thursday the first major step - he called it a "down payment" - of shrinking the Pentagon after a decade of war.

docs.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta outlined on Thursday the first major step -- he called it a "down payment" -- of shrinking the Pentagon after a decade of war. Included in the proposal: limit pay raises for troops, increase health insurance fees for military retirees and close bases in the United States. Of those proposals, our colleagues Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker write that pay-raise limits, though modest, "are certain to ignite a political fight in Congress, which since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has consistently raised military salaries beyond what the Pentagon has recommended."

headline.main: A Quick Roundup of the Pentagon's Proposed Budget Cuts

docs.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL - Expatriates living in Turkey scrambled this week to try to fulfill a new requirement that foreign residents register and pay for national health insurance by Tuesday, January 31, or face a fine said to be 886.50 lira, or about $495.

headline.main: Expats Face Confusing New Law to Buy Insurance in Turkey

docs.abstract: Foreign residents of Turkey have been thrown into a panic over a new law mandating that they buy national health insurance by Tuesday or face a fine. But no one seems to be sure how to sign up, who is required to, or by when.
docs.snippet: Foreign residents of Turkey have been thrown into a panic over a new law mandating that they buy national health insurance by Tuesday or face a fine. But no one seems to be sure how to sign up, who is required to, or by when.

headline.main: Health Insurance Deductibles Doubled in 7 Years, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Average deductibles for employer-based, family health insurance doubled from 2003 to 2010, a report from the Commonwealth Fund finds.
